messageBody:
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
> So said Michael Silverstein on 2002-12-17 --------------------
>
> >That said, it would be nice if Smalltalk supported
> >Interfaces, which I find extremely useful but is not yet
> supported in
> >Smalltalk, to my knowledge.
>
> Smalltalk supports interfaces, in a way; although it supports
> abstract classes even better.
>
> Push a method up to a superclass and, in the superclass, have
> the method answer "SubclassResponsibility" or whatever the
> exact method name is.

I really don't see how it can be said that standard Smalltalk supports
anything like an Interface. I like Interfaces because they are the
purest form of abstraction I've found. Interfaces are completely
agnostic about implementation to the point that they make no assumptions
about which type they are to be applied to.

To tie this into JUnit, any class can implement the Test interface and
automatically be considered a test. Of course JUnit stumbles insofar as
collecting suites (see the static suite() method and my earlier comments
about that), but that's mainly because of its departure from the use of
its own Test interface to define an API for test collection.

Using '^self subclassResponsibility' is a sort of stopgap mechanism for
indicating abstraction, but appears in my opinion to be weaker than
being able to use an 'abstract' modifier. Plus using abstract classes
and methods falls short of interfaces because you are still tied to a
particular hierarchy. Not that this mechanism is bad but it limits your
flexibility to a degree.

> I have found that I don't want interfaces when I work with Ruby or
> Smalltalk: I like the idea that handling methods has nothing
> to do with type.

I don't know what this statement means. Can you elaborate?

From the above, it may appear that I am contradicting my earlier
contention that Smalltalk is a better OO language, but believe me I am
not. Lack of support for interfaces is a nit compared to some of the
horrors I've seen in the Java language. For a taste, try to exploit
class side (static) polymorphism.
